Package MyCode

Class WavHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • MyCode.WavHandler
  • public class WavHandler
extends java.lang.Object
    Handles the extraction and storage of each annotation.

    • Method Detail

      • extractAnnotationsFromWav

        public void extractAnnotationsFromWav()
        Extracts all the annotations from a WAV file.

      • addBufferToTimeRange

        private boolean addBufferToTimeRange​(double extraTime,
                                     int i)
        Handles the process of adding a buffer to the annotation if its less than 1.1 seconds.
        Parameters:
        extraTime - The amount of time that needs to be added to the annotation to make it 1.1 seconds.
        i - The index into the array of annotation times.
        Returns:
        A boolean flag stating whether the issue could be resolved.

      • clearClipsDirectory

        private void clearClipsDirectory()
        Clears the created clips directory.

      • storeAnnotationAsWavFile

        private boolean storeAnnotationAsWavFile​(double[] data,
                                         java.lang.String newFilename,
                                         int numberOfFrames)
        Stores the extracted annotation data as a new wav file.
        Parameters:
        data - The annotation data.
        newFilename - The name of the new file.
        numberOfFrames - How long the annotation is in terms of frames.
        Returns:
        Boolean flag indicating success or failure.

      • extractAnnotation

        private double[] extractAnnotation​(double startTime,
                                   double endtime,
                                   double sampleRate)
        Extracts a single annotation from the wav file.
        Parameters:
        startTime - The start time of the annotation.
        endtime - The end time of the annotation.
        sampleRate - The sampling rate of the recording equipment (I.e. the number of samples per second)
        Returns:
        The recording information corresponding to that annotation. When reading from recordings with multiple channels, we need to be careful since the data is typically organised as sample1L sample1R sample2L sample2R sample3L sample3R...
